questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about tonsils?

choices.text: Bed of the tonsil is formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles.
It is covered by keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium on the medial surface.
Crypta magna is a remnant of the ventral part of second pharyngeal pouch.
A capsule covers the lateral surface of the tonsils.

questions.solution:
The medial surface of the tonsil is covered by non-keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium.

Tonsils are ovoid masses of lymphoid tissue situated in the lateral wall of the oropharynx between the anterior and posterior pillars.

The medial surface of the tonsil is covered in 12-15 crypts. Crypta magna or intratonsillar cleft is the largest & deepest of the crypts. It is situated near the upper part of the tonsil and represents the ventral part of the second pharyngeal pouch.

The lateral surface of the tonsil presents a well-defined fibrous capsule.

The bed of the tonsil is formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles.

questions.text: At what age do the tonsils attain their maximum size?
questions.solution:
The growth of tonsils is rapid around the age of 5-6 years of age and usually reaches their maximum size by 12 years of age.

Tonsillar involution begins at puberty when the reactive lymphoid tissue begins to atrophy, and by old age, only a little tonsillar lymphoid tissue remains.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with oral carcinoma was referred to the ENT department for evaluation. While examining the oral cavity, the consultant asked you to examine the ENT surgeon’s graveyard to check for any induration or ulcers. What is the area being referred to here?
questions.solution:
The area referred to here is the tonsillolingual sulcus which is known as the graveyard of ENT surgeons.

The palatine tonsil is separated from the tongue by a sulcus called the tonsillolingual sulcus, which may be the seat of carcinoma. This area is easily missed during oral examination hence known as the graveyard of ENT surgeons.

questions.text: Which of the following is the main arterial supply of palatine tonsils?

choices.text: Tonsillar branch of the facial artery
Descending palatine branch of maxillary artery
Ascending palatine branch of facial artery

questions.solution:
The main arterial supply of tonsil is by the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.

Five arteries supply the tonsil:

  1. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (the main artery)
  2. Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery
  3. Ascending pharyngeal branch of the external carotid artery
  4. Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery
  5. Descending palatine branches of the maxillary artery

questions.text: You are the second-year ENT resident performing tonsillectomy in a patient with chronic tonsillitis. While creating a dissection plane between the capsule and the bed of the tonsil, you accidentally deepened the incision, injuring the tonsillar bed. Which of the following structures is least likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The lateral pterygoid muscle is not related to the bed of the tonsil and is the least likely structure to be injured in this scenario.

The bed of the tonsil is formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles.

The lower fossa is related to:

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve
  • The styloid process

Outside the superior constrictor, the tonsil is related to:

  • The facial artery
  • Submandibular salivary gland
  • Posterior belly of the digastric muscle
  • Medial pterygoid muscle
  • The angle of the mandible

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was brought to the hospital by his mother with complaints of a sore throat, earache, and pain on swallowing for three days. On examination, the tonsils were enlarged and hyperaemic. Which of the following is the most common organism implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute tonsillitis. The most common organism causing acute tonsillitis in children is β hemolytic streptococcus.

Other causative organisms include:

  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • Haemophilus influenzae

questions.text: A young lady presents to the ENT OPD with the finding shown below. Which of the following group of lymph nodes will primarily enlarge in this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows purulent inflammation of the tonsils suggestive of acute tonsillitis. Jugulo-digastric (tonsillar) lymph nodes will primarily enlarge in this condition.

The lymphatics from the palatine tonsils pierce the superior constrictor muscle and primarily drain into the upper deep cervical nodes (level II), particularly the jugulo-digastric (tonsillar) node situated below the angle of the mandible. So, it is the most likely group of lymph nodes to enlarge in case of acute tonsillitis.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented with a history of fever, sore throat, and dysphagia for three days. Which of the following variants is not expected to be seen on oral examination?
questions.solution:
The patient's history is suggestive of acute tonsillitis. The fibroid variety is a type of chronic tonsillitis and is not expected to be seen in this case.

Depending on the pathology within the tonsillar tissue, acute tonsillitis can be classified into the following types:

  • Acute catarrhal or superficial tonsillitis: Here tonsillitis is a part of generalized pharyngitis and is primarily seen in viral infections.
  • Acute follicular tonsillitis: The infection spreads into the crypts, which become filled with purulent material, presenting at the openings of crypts as yellowish spots.
  • Acute parenchymatous tonsillitis: Here tonsil substance is affected. Tonsil is uniformly enlarged and red.
  • Acute membranous tonsillitis: It is a stage ahead of acute follicular tonsillitis when exudation from the crypts coalesces to form a membrane on the surface of the tonsil.

Types of chronic tonsillitis:

  • Chronic follicular tonsillitis
  • Chronic parenchymal tonsillitis
  • Chronic fibroid tonsillitis

questions.text: An anxious mother brought her 4-year-old-child to the hospital with complaints of sudden onset fever and refusal to eat. On examination, the given finding was noted and he was started on analgesics and antibiotics. Which among the following is not a known complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of acute tonsillitis. Excessive bleeding is not a known complication of this condition.

Complications of acute tonsillitis:

  • Chronic tonsillitis - chronic infection may persist in lymphoid follicles of the tonsil in the form of microabscesses
  • Peritonsillar abscess
  • Parapharyngeal abscess 
  • Cervical abscess due to suppuration of jugulodigastric lymph nodes
  • Acute otitis media
  • Rheumatic fever - often seen in association with tonsillitis due to group A β-hemolytic streptococci
  • Acute glomerulonephritis (rare)
  • Subacute bacterial endocarditis - acute tonsillitis in a patient with valvular heart disease may be complicated by endocarditis. It is usually due to Streptococcus viridans infection

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis?
questions.solution:
The tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

The tonsils and tonsillar fossa are supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve. The glossopharyngeal nerve and the styloid process lie in relation to the lower part of the tonsillar fossa. Therefore, any irritation or pain can be referred to the ear along the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal (Jacobson's) nerve.

Causes of referred otalgia via the glossopharyngeal nerve include acute pharyngitis, tonsillitis, peritonsillar abscess, post-tonsillectomy, foreign bodies embedded in the base of the tongue or tonsillar area and an elongated styloid process (Eagle's syndrome).

The ear receives extensive sensory innervation via four cranial nerves (V, VII, IX, and X) and two spinal segments (C2 and C3).

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented to the ENT surgeon with a history of loud snoring, restless sleep leading to daytime somnolence, and poor academic performance. Her medical history was unremarkable, except for recurrent episodes of acute tonsillitis. Which of the following types of tonsillitis may be implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of obstructive sleep apnea syndrome(OSAS) secondary to chronic parenchymatous tonsillitis.

In parenchymatous tonsillitis, the tonsils grow very large following repeated attacks of acute tonsillitis and lead to obstructive symptoms, including OSAS. 

Types of chronic tonsillitis: 

  • Chronic follicular tonsillitis- tonsillar crypts are full of infected cheesy material, which shows on the surface as yellowish spots. 
  • Chronic parenchymatous tonsillitis- there is hyperplasia of lymphoid tissue. Tonsils are very much enlarged and may interfere with speech, deglutition, and respiration. Attacks of sleep apnoea may occur. Long-standing cases develop features of cor pulmonale.
  • Chronic fibroid tonsillitis- tonsils are tiny but infected, with a history of repeated sore throats.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the ENT department working up a case of chronic follicular tonsillitis. Which of the following clinical signs would you not expect to see in this patient on examining the oral cavity?
questions.solution:
Müller's sign is the pulsation of uvula during systole seen in aortic regurgitation. It is not seen in patients with chronic tonsillitis.

The classical signs of chronic tonsillitis are:

  • Irwin-Moore sign- tonsils are tiny, but pressure on the anterior pillar expresses frank pus or cheesy material.
  • Bluish Flushing of anterior pillars compared to the rest of the pharyngeal mucosa is a vital sign of chronic tonsillar infection.
  • Enlargement of jugulo-digastric lymph nodes even in the absence of acute infection is a reliable sign of chronic tonsillitis. During acute attacks, the nodes enlarge further and become tender.

questions.text: An ENT junior resident observed a symptomless yellowish swelling over the tonsil when he was examining a patient for a buccal sore. The swelling was easily drained. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a tonsillar cyst. It is a condition due to blockage of a tonsillar crypt and appears as a yellowish swelling over the tonsil. Very often, it is symptomless and can be easily drained.

Option A: Intratonsillar abscess is an accumulation of pus within the substance of the tonsil. It usually follows a blockage of the opening of the crypt in acute follicular tonsillitis. There is marked local pain and dysphagia. Tonsil appears swollen and red.

Option B: Tonsilloliths (calculus of the tonsil) are seen in chronic tonsillitis when its crypt is blocked with retention of debris. Inorganic salts of calcium and magnesium are then deposited leading to the formation of a stone. It may gradually enlarge and then ulcerate through the tonsil. It generally causes local discomfort or foreign body sensation.

Option D: In follicular tonsillitis, purulent material is present at the opening of the crypts as yellow dots. It presents with fever, dysphagia, and sore throat.

questions.text: On examining the oral cavity of a patient who presented with fever and a sore throat, you notice a greyish-white membrane over the tonsils. Which of the following conditions would you not consider as a differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ludwig’s angina is not associated with the formation of a grey-white membrane. It is characterized by rapidly spreading infection of the sublingual space initially and later the submaxillary space, often dentogenic in origin.

D/D for membrane over tonsil:

  • Streptococcus & other pyogenic organisms
  • Diphtheria
  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Vincent’s angina
  • Leukemia
  • Candida
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Malignancy
  • Apthous ulcer
  • Traumatic ulcer

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is implicated in Vincent’s angina?
questions.solution:
Vincent’s angina is caused by fusiform bacilli and spirochaetes, namely Bacillus fusiformis and Borrelia vincenti.

The condition presents with low-grade fever and sore throat, and a membrane over the tonsil. The membrane is easily removed to reveal irregular ulcers over the tonsil. Throat swab will show both the organisms typical of the disease, namely fusiform bacilli and spirochaetes.

questions.text: A worried mother brought her 6-year-old unimmunized child to the ER with complaints of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. On examination, a pseudomembrane was noted in the oral cavity along with the neck finding as shown in the image. Which of the following statements is true regarding the membrane observed?

choices.text: Firmly adherent and bleeds on removal

questions.solution:
The given clinical history and bull-neck appearance (image) point to the diagnosis of diphtheria. The diphtheritic membrane is firmly adherent and bleeds on removal.

A greyish-white membrane forms over the tonsils in the oropharynx and spreads to the soft palate and posterior pharyngeal wall. The membrane in diphtheria extends beyond the tonsils onto the soft palate and is dirty grey. It is adherent, and its removal leaves a bleeding surface. In the larynx, the diphtheritic membrane may cause airway obstruction.

Cervical lymph nodes, particularly the jugulodigastric, become enlarged and tender, sometimes presenting a bull-neck appearance. The patient is ill and toxaemic, but fever seldom rises above 38°C.

questions.text: Which of the following complications would you not expect to see in a patient diagnosed with diphtheria?
questions.solution:
Hard palate paralysis is not seen in diphtheria.

The exotoxin produced by C. diphtheriae is toxic to the heart and nerves. It causes:

  • Myocarditis
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Acute circulatory failure

Neurological complications include paralysis of the soft-palate, diaphragm, and ocular muscles. In the larynx, the diphtheric membrane may cause airway obstruction.

questions.text: Following finding was noted in a patient who presented with difficulty breathing and a bull-neck appearance. Which of the following statements is true regarding the treatment of this patient?

choices.text: Treatment is started after the culture comes positive
Sensitivity to antitoxin should be tested prior to therapy

questions.solution:
The pseudomembrane on oral examination and bull neck appearance is characteristic of diphtheria. Sensitivity to diphtheria antitoxin is common and should be tested prior to the initiation of therapy.

Treatment is started on clinical suspicion without waiting for the culture report. The aim is to neutralize the free exotoxin still circulating in the blood and to kill the organisms producing this exotoxin.

Antitoxins:

  • Dose- based on the site involved, duration, and severity of the disease
    • If < 48 hours or just confined to tonsils: 20,000–40,000 units
    • If > 48 hours or extensive membrane: 80,000–120,000 units
  • Given by i.v. infusion in saline in about 60 min
  • Sensitivity tested by a conjunctival or intracutaneous test with diluted antitoxin
  • If a hypersensitivity reaction occurs, desensitization should be done

Antibiotics:

  • Benzyl penicillin 600 mg 6 hourly for 7 days
  • Erythromycin is used in penicillin-sensitive individuals (500 mg 6 hourly orally)

questions.text: Which of the following cases cannot be posted for an elective tonsillectomy?

choices.text: A young adult with chronic tonsillitis refractory to treatment
A patient with unilateral enlargement of tonsil with suspected malignancy
A middle-aged man with recurrent quinsy

questions.solution:
Acute tonsillitis is a contraindication for tonsillectomy and hence, cannot be posted for elective surgery.

Acute tonsillitis or any upper respiratory tract infection is a contraindication for tonsillectomy since there is an increased chance of hemorrhage and sepsis.

Indications of tonsillectomy are:

  • Recurrent episodes of acute tonsillitis – most common indication
    Seven or more episodes in 1 year, or
    Five episodes per year for 2 years, or
    Three episodes per year for 3 years, or
    Two weeks or more of lost school or work in 1 year
  • Febrile seizures due to fever in tonsillitis
  • Peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) - recurrent episodes in adults and a single episode in children
  • Hypertrophy of tonsils causing airway obstruction, difficulty in deglutition, interference with speech
  • Unilateral enlargement of tonsil with suspicion of malignancy
  • Chronic tonsillitis with bad taste or halitosis which is unresponsive to medical treatment (relative indication)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to perform a tonsillectomy?
questions.solution:
Diphtheria and streptococcal carriers are relative indications for tonsillectomy and the surgery can be safely performed in patients presenting with the same.

Contraindications for tonsillectomy:

  • Haemoglobin level less than 10 g%.
  • Presence of acute infection in upper respiratory tract, even acute tonsillitis. Bleeding is more in the presence of acute infection.
  • Children under 3 years of age.
  • Overt or submucous cleft palate.
  • Bleeding disorders, e.g. leukaemia, purpura, aplastic anaemia or haemophilia.
  • At the time of epidemic of polio.
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g. diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension or asthma.
  • Tonsillectomy is avoided during the period of menses.

questions.text: A patient develops bleeding from the surgical site five hours after an elective tonsillectomy. Which among the following would best describe the condition?
questions.solution:
Bleeding from the surgical site within a period of 24 hours is categorised as a reactionary haemorrhage.

Primary haemorrhage - occurs at the time of operation.

Secondary haemorrhage - usually seen between the fifth to tenth postoperative days.

questions.text: While preparing for a procedure, the patient was kept in a specific position as depicted in the image. In which of the following procedures is this position not adopted?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Rose's position and it is not a suitable position to perform a direct laryngoscopy. The barking-dog position is used for direct laryngoscopy.

Rose’s position: The patient lies supine with head extended by placing a pillow under the shoulders. It is followed in adenoidectomy, tonsillectomy, and tracheostomy.

Barking-dog position: Patient lies supine. The Head is elevated by 10–15 cm by placing a pillow under the occiput or raising the operation table’s head flap. The neck is flexed on the thorax and the head is extended on the atlanto-occipital joint.
